factoid: Natásha reviewed her kingdom.
Natásha tested her power.
Natásha made sure everyone was submissive.
The situation was dull.
Natásha went to the ballroom.
Natásha picked up her guitar.
Natásha sat down in a dark corner behind a bookcase.
Natásha began to run her fingers over the strings in the bass.
Natásha picked out a passage she recalled from an opera she had heard in Petersburg with Prince Andrew.
Natásha had heard an opera in Petersburg with Prince Andrew.
The opera was heard with Prince Andrew.
The music Natásha drew from the guitar had no meaning for other listeners.
In Natásha's imagination a whole series of reminiscences arose from those sounds.
Natásha sat behind the bookcase.
Natásha's eyes were fixed on a streak of light escaping from the pantry door.
Natásha listened to herself.
Natásha pondered.
Natásha was in a mood for brooding on the past.
Sónya passed to the pantry with a glass in her hand.
Natásha glanced at Sónya.
Natásha glanced at the crack in the pantry door.
Natásha remembered the light falling through that crack once before.
Natásha thought that Sónya was passing with a glass in her hand.
Natásha thought "Yes it was exactly the same."
Natásha cried "Sónya, what is this?" while twanging a thick string.
Sónya said "Oh, you are there!" with a start.
Sónya came near and listened.
Natásha ventured "I don’t know. A storm?" timidly.
Natásha was afraid of being wrong.
Natásha thought that Sónya started and came up smiling timidly when all this happened before.
Natásha thought that Sónya had something lacking.
Natásha said "No, it’s the chorus from The Water-Carrier, listen!"
Natásha sang the air of the chorus so that Sónya could hear it.
Natásha asked Sónya "Where were you going?"
Sónya answered that she was going to change the water in the glass and was just finishing the design.
Natásha said "You always find something to do, but I can’t."
Natásha asked where Nicholas was.
Sónya replied that Nicholas was asleep.
Natásha told Sónya to go and wake Nicholas.
Natásha told Sónya to tell Nicholas that she wants him to come and sing.
Natásha sat for a while.
Natásha wondered what the meaning of all that had happened before could be.
Natásha did not solve the problem.
Natásha did not regret not having solved it.
Natásha passed in fancy to the time when she was with Nicholas and he was looking at her with a lover's eyes.
Natásha thought "Oh, if only he would come quicker!"
Natásha thought "I am so afraid it will never be!"
Natásha thought "I am growing old—that's the thing!"
Natásha thought "There won't then be in me what there is now."
Natásha thought "Perhaps he'll come today, will come immediately."
Natásha thought "Perhaps he has come and is sitting in the drawing room."
Natásha thought "Perhaps he came yesterday and I have forgotten it."
Natásha rose.
Natásha put down the guitar.
Natásha went to the drawing room.
The domestic circle, tutors, governesses, and guests were already at the tea table.
The servants stood around the table.
Prince Andrew was not at the tea table.
Life was going on as before.
The old count said "Ah, here she is!" when he saw Natásha enter.
The old count said "Well, sit down by me."
Natásha stayed by her mother.
Natásha glanced around as if looking for something.
Natásha muttered "Mamma!" and "give him to me, give him, Mamma, quickly, quickly!"
Natásha had difficulty repressing her sobs.
Natásha sat down at the table.
Natásha listened to the conversation between the elders and Nicholas.
Nicholas had come to the table.
Natásha thought "My God, my God! The same faces… Papa holding his cup and blowing in the same way!"
Natásha felt with horror a sense of repulsion rising up in her for the whole household.
Natásha felt that the household was always the same.
After tea, Nicholas, Sónya, and Natásha went to the sitting room.
They went to their favorite corner where their most intimate talks always began.
Natásha said to her brother "Does it ever happen to you?"
Natásha said to her brother "Does it ever happen to you to feel as if there were nothing more to come—nothing; that everything good is past?"
Natásha said to her brother "Does it ever happen to you to feel not exactly dull, but sad?"
The brother replied "I should think so!"
The brother said "I have felt like that when everything was all right and everyone was cheerful."
The brother said "The thought has come into my mind that I was already tired of it all, and that we must all die."
The brother said "Once in the regiment I had not gone to some merrymaking where there was music… and suddenly I felt so depressed."
